Package edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre

Class InitialState

java.lang.Object
edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.InitialState
All Implemented Interfaces:
FiniteState, Logical, State, Serializable, Comparable<Logical>
public class InitialState extends Object implements Serializable, Logical, FiniteState
An initial state is a finite state which uses a logical expression to explicitly set the values of some fluents and then assumes default values for all other fluents. The expression used to construct this state should be something which can be converted to an effect, meaning it should be deterministic (no disjunctions) and should use assignments rather than comparisons to specify the values of fluents.

When a fluent with no characters is not explicitly assigned a value, we assume the default value based on the fluent's type.

When a character's beliefs about a fluent are not explicitly stated, we assume the character believes its actual value. For example, if no value is specified for the fluent believes(B, alive(A)), then it will have the same value as alive(A).

When beliefs about fluents with multiple characters are not explicitly stated, we assume the value is the same as the value assigned to the same fluent with with the last character removed. For example, if no value is specified for believes(A, believes(B, alive(A))) then it will have the same value as believes(A, alive(A)).

Author:
Stephen G. Ware

    • apply

      public InitialState apply(Function<Object,Object> function)
      Description copied from interface: Logical
      Applies a given function to every part of this logical formula and then creates a new logical formula of this same type using the results returned from the function. If, for every part of this formula, the function always returns its input as output with no changes, this method should return this object (not just any object that is equal to this object).
      Specified by:
      apply in interface Logical
      Parameters:
      function - the function to apply to all parts of this formula
      Returns:
      a logical formula of the same type as this formula made from the returned objects, or this object if no parts were changed by the function
